March 20, 2016: Fiction
THE GANGSTER, by Clive Cussler and Justin Scott. (Putnam.) In the ninth book in
this series, set in 1906, the New York detective Isaac Bell contends with a crime
boss passing as a respectable businessman and a tycoon’s plot against President
Theodore Roosevelt.
ALL THE LIGHT WE CANNOT SEE, by Anthony Doerr. (Scribner.) The lives of a
blind French girl and a gadget-obsessed German boy before and during World War
II.
THE GIRL ON THE TRAIN, by Paula Hawkins. (Riverhead.) A psychological thriller
set in the environs of London.
THE NIGHTINGALE, by Kristin Hannah. (St. Martin's.) Two sisters in World War II
France: one struggling to survive in the countryside, the other joining the Resistance
in Paris.
A GIRL'S GUIDE TO MOVING ON, by Debbie Macomber. (Ballantine.) A mother
and her daughter-in-law both leave unhappy marriages and take up with new men.
COMETH THE HOUR, by Jeffrey Archer. (St. Martin's.) The sixth and penultimate
book of the Clifton Chronicles brings the Cliftons and the Barringtons into the 1970s.
MY NAME IS LUCY BARTON, by Elizabeth Strout. (Random House.) A woman
struggles with memories of her impoverished and disturbing childhood and its effect
on the present as she attempts to reconcile with her mother.
GO SET A WATCHMAN, by Harper Lee. (Harper.) In the mid-1950s, a grown-up
Jean Louise Finch returns home to find that her adored father is not as perfect as
she believed.
THE WIDOW, by Fiona Barton. (New American Library.) When a suspect in a
missing-child case dies, reporters and the police think they’ll get the real story from
his widow. They’re wrong.
FIND HER, by Lisa Gardner. (Dutton.) The Boston detective D. D. Warren hunts for
a missing woman who was kidnapped and abused as a college student and may
have become a vigilante.
NYPD RED 4, by James Patterson and Marshall Karp. (Little, Brown.) Detective
Zach Jordan and his partner, members of an elite task force that protects the rich
and famous, pursue a cold-blooded killer.
A FEW OF THE GIRLS, by Maeve Binchy. (Knopf.) A collection of the stories that
spans the career of the Irish writer, who died in 2012.
AFTER YOU, by Jojo Moyes. (Pamela Dorman/Viking.) In a sequel to “Me Before
You,” Louisa Clark tries to put her life back together after the death of Will Traynor,
March 20, 2016
Non-Fiction
WHEN BREATH BECOMES AIR, by Paul Kalanithi. (Random House.) A memoir
by a physician who received a diagnosis of Stage IV lung cancer at the age of 36.
BETWEEN THE WORLD AND ME, by Ta-Nehisi Coates. (Spiegel & Grau.) A
meditation on race in America; winner of the National Book Award.
DARK MONEY, by Jane Mayer. (Doubleday.) An account of how the Koch
brothers and other super-wealthy donors deployed their money to change
American politics.
PLAYING TO THE EDGE, by Michael V. Hayden. (Penguin Press.) Press) A
former C.I.A. director defends his policies.
SEVEN BRIEF LESSONS ON PHYSICS, by Carlo Rovelli. (Riverhead.) An
introduction to modern physics.
EVICTED, by Matthew Desmond. (Crown.) How poor people repeatedly lose their
homes while landlords profit.
AMERICAN GIRLS, by Nancy Jo Sales. (Knopf.) How social media has changed
the way girls grow up.
A MOTHER'S RECKONING, by Sue Klebold. (Crown.) The mother of one of the
Columbine shooters wrestles with her grief and guilt and discusses how parents
can become more aware of the signs of mental illness in teenagers.
THE NAME OF GOD IS MERCY, by Pope Francis with Andrea Tornielli. (Random
House.) In a conversation with a Vatican reporter, the pontiff explores the
cornerstone of his faith.
THE ROAD TO LITTLE DRIBBLING, by Bill Bryson. (Doubleday.) An American
expatriate travels around his adopted country, Britain.
BEING MORTAL, by Atul Gawande. (Metropolitan/Holt.) The surgeon and New
Yorker writer considers how doctors fail patients at the end of life and how they
can do better.
THE IMMORTAL IRISHMAN, by Timothy Egan. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt.) The
life of Thomas Francis Meagher, an Irish revolutionary who fled to America and
was active in Irish-American politics, becoming the general of New York’s Irish
Brigade during the Civil War.
AND THEN ALL HELL BROKE LOOSE, by Richard Engel. (Simon & Schuster.)
NBC’s chief foreign correspondent discusses the Arab Spring and war in the
Middle East.
THE LEGENDS CLUB, by John Feinstein. (Doubleday.) A sportswriter’s account
